message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has painful lesions in his mouth which are a common symptom of aphthous stomatitis. The fact that he has had similar lesions in the past and has not had any genital or anal lesions also supports this diagnosis. Pemphigus vulgaris and oral thrush are less likely because they usually have different symptoms and presentation. Herpangina may cause similar symptoms but usually occurs in younger children and is associated with fever and sore throat, which are not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia and other medical sources for help. The presentation of painful lesions in the mouth, recurring every year, and resolving without treatment after 10 days, suggests that the most likely diagnosis is Aphthous stomatitis. Pemphigus vulgaris presents with painful erosions and lesions on the mucous membrane. Oral thrush presents with white patches in the mouth. Herpangina presents with small, painful blisters on the back of the throat and tonsils.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the photograph indicate the presence of painful lesions in the mouth, which are the hallmark presentation of Aphthous stomatitis. Pemphigus vulgaris presents with blisters in the mouth and skin, while oral thrush causes white patches in the mouth. Herpangina presents with fever, sore throat, and small blisters or ulcers in the back of the mouth or throat.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lesions are shallow and painful, which suggest Aphthous stomatitis. Pemphigus vulgaris and oral thrush usually have different appearances, and herpangina is mostly seen in children. The stress of approaching his senior year might have triggered the recurrence of his lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The painful lesions in the mouth that resolve without treatment after approximately 10 days suggest the most likely diagnosis is aphthous stomatitis. None of the other options match the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the photograph of his oral cavity suggest the most likely diagnosis is Aphthous stomatitis. Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by superficial blisters and oral thrush usually presents as a white plaque, while herpangina presents with fever and ulcers on the throat and tonsils.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The painful lesions in the mouth that resolve without treatment after approximately 10 days suggest Aphthous stomatitis, which is commonly linked to stress. The other options are either caused by a fungal infection (oral thrush), a viral infection (herpangina), or an autoimmune disorder (pemphigus vulgaris), which are less likely given the clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The painful lesions in the mouth, absence of any genital or anal lesions, and the photograph shown in the question suggest aphthous stomatitis as the most likely diagnosis. Pemphigus vulgaris presents as blistering lesions, oral thrush presents with white patches on the tongue and oral mucosa, and herpangina presents with fever, sore throat, and small vesicular lesions in the posterior oropharynx, none of which match the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of painful lesions in the mouth that resolve without treatment after 10 days suggests Aphthous stomatitis. Pemphigus vulgaris presents with larger blisters, oral thrush presents with white plaques, and herpangina presents with ulcers in the throat and tonsils.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lesion in the photograph shows a single, shallow, round ulcer with a white or yellow-gray base surrounded by a red halo on the lower lip, which is consistent with aphthous stomatitis. Pemphigus vulgaris presents with blisters, oral thrush presents with white patches, and herpangina presents with multiple small blisters or ulcers in the back of the throat.
